title: 103_s1178
content: The Act may be cited as the "Great Lakes Federal Effectiveness Act" and establishes the Great Lakes Research Council. The Great Lakes Research Council is established to advise and coordinate federal research activities for ecosystem protection in the Great Lakes. They will prepare an assessment of research activities needed within one year of the Act's enactment. The Great Lakes Research Council will assess research activities required for ecosystem protection in the Great Lakes as per the Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement goals. They will also evaluate existing Federal expertise and capabilities in fulfilling these goals. The Great Lakes Research Council will assess research activities needed to fulfill the Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement goals, evaluate existing Federal expertise and capabilities, and provide recommendations for Federal research priorities on the Great Lakes. The Great Lakes Research Council will assess existing Federal Great Lakes research programs, projects, facilities, and personnel. They will make recommendations for long-term and short-term research priorities based on this assessment. Additionally, they will identify topics for meetings and conferences, make recommendations for data collection, and enhance research and management protocols for the Great Lakes ecosystem. The Great Lakes Research Council will participate in meetings, workshops, and conferences on research issues, recommend data collection methods, establish a comprehensive data base, and ensure timely dissemination of research findings. The Great Lakes Research Council aims to advise on data collection methods, establish a comprehensive data base, and ensure timely dissemination of research findings. The Council is comprised of a research manager with extensive knowledge and scientific expertise. The Great Lakes Research Council, comprised of research managers from various agencies, aims to advise on data collection methods and ensure timely dissemination of research findings. The Council utilizes existing mechanisms like the Great Lakes Research Inventory for information sharing. The Great Lakes Research Council includes agencies like the EPA, NOAA, USCG, USFWS, and other relevant federal departments. Non-Federal employees can also serve as ex officio members. The Chairperson is elected by members for a two-year term. The Council membership determines instrumentality. Non-Federal employees can serve as ex officio members. The Chairperson is elected by members for a two-year term and cannot serve more than two consecutive terms. Members are entitled to compensation for travel expenses. Interagency cooperation is required among department heads. The Council Chairperson can serve for more than two consecutive terms. Members receive compensation for travel expenses. Interagency cooperation is mandatory for implementing recommendations. Federal Government members of the Council must cooperate to implement recommendations, provide necessary personnel, services, or facilities upon request, and furnish data as needed. The Council will invite the International Joint Commission to serve as the principal coordinating body and may reimburse costs for activities. This Act will not affect the authority of any Federal agency to conduct Great Lakes research. Sec. 105 of this Act defines the terms used, including "Council" as the Great Lakes Research Council, "Great Lakes" as specific lakes and connecting waters, and "Great Lakes research" as the application of scientific expertise. The Great Lakes Research Council defines "Great Lakes" as specific lakes and connecting waters, including the St. Marys River, St. Clair River, Lake St. Clair, Detroit River, Niagara River, and St. Lawrence River. Great Lakes research involves scientific and engineering expertise to study the ecosystem. The Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement is a bilateral agreement between the US and Canada signed in 1978 and amended in 1987.
